user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtMem2BinFileCmp:
```c
bool UtMem2BinFileCmp(const void *Memory, const char *Filename)
{
    FILE *       fp;
    const uint8 *MemByte = Memory;
    int          FileByte;
    bool         Success;
    uint32       i;

    Success = true;
    if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "r")))
    {
        for (i = 0; (FileByte = fgetc(fp)) != EOF; i++)
        {
            if (MemByte[i] != FileByte)
            {
                Success = false;
                printf("UtMem2BinFileCmp: Miscompare in file: %s, byte offset: %lu, expected: %u, found: %u\n",
                       Filename, (unsigned long)i, (unsigned int)MemByte[i], (unsigned int)FileByte);
                break;
            }
        }
        fclose(fp);
    }
    else
    {
        Success = false;
        printf("UtMem2BinFileCmp: Error Opening File: %s, %s\n", Filename, strerror(errno));
        UtAssert_True(false, "UtMem2BinFileCmp: Error Opening File");
    }

    return Success;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtMem2BinFileCmp:
typedef uint8_t   uint8
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
#define UtAssert_True(Expression, __VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(Expression,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
...
UtAssert_CaseType_t UtAssert_GetContext(void)
{
    return DefaultContext;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I reviewed the function and related macros/typedefs for use of compiler-specific language extensions. I did not find any explicit compiler extensions such as: __attribute__ or other __attribute__ variants, __builtin_* or __extension__ identifiers, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, inline assembler (__asm__), labels-as-values (&&label), pragmas that are compiler-specific (e.g. #pragma GCC), or other vendor-specific keywords documented as extensions. The variadic macro (UtAssert_True using __VA_ARGS__) is a standard C99 feature, and the typedefs using stdint types (uint8_t/uint32_t) are standard. The implicit conversion from void* to an object pointer (const uint8 *MemByte = Memory) is permitted in C (not a compiler extension). Therefore there are no code fragments in the provided code that require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (use of language extensions).
